Appendix C: Diabetes Footcare Pathway (Staging) Appendix D: Diabetes Footcare Pathway (Referral) Appendix E: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
To summarise the referral pathways and the first line antibiotic management of patients with active diabetes foot ulcers.
To ensure continuity of treatment and care is consistent across all patients being referred into the hospital from the community.
To promote consistent and standardised care, to the highest standards possible, for patients with diabetic foot infections.
To outline the actions necessary for managing these conditions, thereby reducing risk to patients.
To provide an overview of stratification of diabetes foot ulcer management and pathways of care affecting patients being referred into hospital from the community.
Whilst based on scientific evidence or professional consensus, these guidelines are not intended to replace clinical judgement.

This guideline is adopted and acknowledged from Provide Policy on “Antibiotic Management of Diabetes Foot Ulcers in Mid Essex” (2016 & 2018) and from CCG Agreed “Mid-Essex Locality Diabetes Footcare Pathway” (2013).
Background

The Diabetes Multi-disciplinary Footcare (MDFC) Team is based in the Diabetes Centre at Broomfield Hospital and consists of Podiatrists and Diabetologists, with support from Diabetes Specialist Nurses (DSNs), Diabetes Dieticians and Orthotists.
The community teams referring into Broomfield Hospital are based in a dedicated network of community podiatry clinics, and from GP teams based at practice level.
Staff and Training
All podiatry and multi-disciplinary diabetes staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date.
As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure they have the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

After these steps have been undertaken it is the responsibility of the individual staff member to update their knowledge of current research and guidelines as part of their continuing professional development.
Patient Management
All patients to be managed in line with the appendixed pathways:
Appendix A: Antibiotic Pathway for Diabetic Foot Ulcers being admitted from the Community;
Appendix B: Antibiotic Pathway for Diabetic Foot Ulcers on Admission to Hospital;
Appendix C: Diabetes Footcare Pathway (Staging);
Appendix D: Diabetes Footcare Pathway (Referral).
Overview of Antibiotic Management of Diabetes Foot Ulcers
Foot infections are a common and serious problem in people with diabetes.

Diabetic Foot Infections typically begin in a wound, most often a neuropathic ulceration. While all wounds are colonised with micro-organisms, the presence of infection is defined by >2 classic findings of inflammation or purulence (IDSA 2012). Infections are then classified into mild (superficial and limited in size and depth), moderate (deeper or more extensive), or severe (accompanied by systemic signs or metabolic disturbances). This classification system, along with a vascular assessment, helps determine which patients should be hospitalised, which may require special imaging procedures or surgical interventions, and which will require amputation.

Most diabetic foot infections are polymicrobial, with aerobic gram positive cocci, and especially staphylococci, the most common causative organisms. Aerobic gram negative bacilli are frequently co-pathogens in infections that are chronic or follow antibiotic treatment, and obligate anaerobes may be co- pathogens in ischaemic or necrotic wounds.

Wounds without evidence of soft tissue or bone infection do not require antibiotic therapy. Not all diabetic ulcers should be considered infected. A simple ulcer with exudates does not on its own merit antimicrobial therapy. For infected wounds, obtain a post debridement specimen (preferably of tissue) for aerobic and anaerobic culture.

Empiric antibiotic therapy can be narrowly targeted at gram positive cocci in many acutely infected patients, but those at risk for infection with antibiotic resistant organisms or with chronic, previously treated, or severe infections usually require broader spectrum regimes.

Osteomyelitis occurs in many diabetic patients with a foot wound and can be difficult to diagnose and treat, often requiring prolonged antibiotic therapy. These patients should be treated within a multi-disciplinary foot care team.

Most diabetic foot infections require some surgical intervention ranging from minor sharp debridement carried out in the community by podiatrists to major resection and amputation carried out in the acute sector. Wounds must also be properly dressed and offloaded of pressure and followed up regularly. An ischaemic foot may require re-vascularisation.
Recommendation for Good Antibiotic Usage with Diabetes Foot Ulcers

Skin ulcers will usually be colonised by many organisms. Significance is established by clinical signs of infection & probable type of organism i.e. treat if bedside indication of infection, don't just treat the wound swab results.
Prescribe an antibiotic only where there is likely to be a clear clinical benefit and for as short a time as possible. The wound swab results can help inform choice of antibiotics.
If systemically unwell; suspicion of septicaemia or positive blood culture always treat early and aggressively in accordance with Sepsis Six pathways.
Refer to MEHT Trust wide antibiotic policy to be read in conjunction with this policy.
Refer to and comply with MEHT policy on infection prevention to minimise the risk of a health care acquired infection.

table_items.text: Two or more signs of inflammation surrounding ulcer:
Signs of inflammation surrounding ulcer (as mild criteria)
Wet Gangrene; Infection Tracking beneath fascia; Abscess Formation
and/or Localised dry gangrene and/or Any deep tissue involvement
Sepsis* 2 or more of: Temperature <36 or > 38.3̊C Heart rate > 90bpm
Borderline admission Lymphangitic streaking Failure to respond to antibiotics
Respiratory rate >20 breaths/min WCC <4 or >12 Acutely altered mental state

data.text: Sampling from the Ulcer Site
Do not swab uninfected ulcers routinely;
For infected ulcers, take an appropriate sample before starting antibiotics;
A superficial swab of an ulcer is not sufficient;
In all instances, clean the ulcer with saline and debride;
The best specimens for culture are curettage or tissue biopsy from the base of the ulcer after cleaning or debridement.
A fresh wound swab from the base of the ulcer after cleaning and debridement is also acceptable
Empirical Treatment

table_items.text: Mild Infection Review antibiotics after one week with microbiology results
MRSA suspected/confirmed: Doxycycline 100mg twice daily tablet. Penicillin allergy: Clindamycin 450mg 4 times daily tablet.
Moderate Review antibiotics after one week with microbiology results (after 48 hours if inpatient).
Co-Amoxiclav 625mg 3 times daily tablets or 1.2g IV 3 times daily if admission required.
MRSA Suspected/confirmed: Add Vancomycin 1g twice daily IV to regimen. Penicillin allergy: Clindamycin 450mg 4 times daily tablet or 600mg 4 times daily IV if admission required.
Severe Review antibiotics after 48 hours with microbiology results.
MRSA suspected/confirmed: Add Vancomycin 1g twice a day IV to regimen. Penicillin allergy: Meropenem 1g 3 times a day IV.

data.text: Combination Therapy is used for the following reasons:
To provide broad spectrum activity;
To prevent the emergence of resistant strains;
To provide synergistic action.

Consider adding metronidazole PO 400mg tds (only use IV if oral route not available) - if anaerobes suspected or identified, if gram negative organism identified, or if no evidence of improvement after 4 weeks.

Consider adding rifampicin 300mg bd or tds orally for the first 2-3 weeks of treating probable well-localised osteomyelitis, as good bone penetrance and better tolerated than fusidic acid. To only be given in combination with other antibiotic (e.g. flucloxacillin) to aid synergy on bone infection. To check for wide range of potential drug interactions (via its hepatic metabolism) prior to prescribing.

Patients who are prescribed ciprofloxacin, clindamycin or a cephalosporin should be counselled about what to do if significant new diarrhoea developed, as this can be associated with the development of C. difficile infection.

Co-trimoxazole PO 960mg bd has been used in the UK as off-licence third line therapy for mild-moderate infected diabetes foot ulcers. If used beware contraindication if on methotrexate, severe liver failure, or previous allergy to trimethoprim.
Antimicrobial Stewardship

The prevalence of antimicrobial resistance has risen sharply over the last 40 years. Few new antimicrobials have been developed. Increased pressure on existing antibiotics, greater challenges in treating patient's inappropriate use of antimicrobials increases the risk to patients of colonisation and infection with resistant organisms and later transmission (NICE Guideline NG15 2015, NICE Guideline NG63 2017).
A START SMART – THEN FOCUS approach is recommended for all antibiotic prescriptions. More information:
http://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/4 17032/Start_Smart_Then_Focus_FINAL.PDF
9.2.1 START SMART – this means:
Do not start antimicrobial therapy unless there is clear clinical evidence of infection;
Take a thorough drug allergy history;
Initiate prompt effective antibiotic treatment within 1 hour of diagnosis (or as soon as possible) in patients with severe sepsis or life threatening infections;
Avoid inappropriate use of Broad –spectrum antibiotics;
Comply with local antimicrobial prescribing guidance;
Document clinical indication (and disease severity if appropriate), drug name ,dose and route in clinical notes;
Include review/stop date or duration;
Obtain cultures prior to commencing therapy where possible(but do not delay therapy).
9.2.2 Then FOCUS – This means:
Reviewing the clinical diagnosis and the continuing need for antibiotics at 48- 72 hours and documenting a clear plan of action – the antimicrobial prescribing decision.
9.2.3 Another toolkit:
TARGET Antibiotic toolkit- ‘Treat Antibiotics responsibly,guidance,education,tools.
To View: http://www.rcgp.org.uk/clinical-and-research/toolkits/target-antibiotic- toolkit.aspx
Osteomyelitis
Diagnosis and Investigation of Possible Osteomyelitis
There should be a high index of suspicion for osteomyelitis in patients with one or more of:
An ulcer area >2cm, an ESR of > 70, visible cortical bone in the ulcer and a positive probe-to –bone test.
Empirical antibiotics are indicated for visible cancellous bone in the ulcer or bone fragments exuding from the ulcer. Do not delay starting therapy for suspected osteomyelitis.
Urgent investigations – Plain x-ray of infected limb, though is often be normal in the first weeks of acute osteomyelitis.
If plain x-ray negative, and diagnostic uncertainty, consider an MRI Scan
If MRI scan negative, treat empirically as a moderate/severely infected ulcer and repeat X-ray in 2-3 weeks.
Sampling- Sampling should be taken before antibiotics are started but not wait for result to start narrow-spectrum antibiotic if moderate to severe
infection.
Bone biopsy is the only reliable source for culture to define the pathogenic organism(s), and is sometimes needed in complex cases.
Treatment of Osteomyelitis
10.2.1 All Empiric antibiotics should be reviewed once microbiology results are available. Drugs marked in Red contain penicillin.

table_items.text: Acute Osteomyelitis Give antibiotics for 48 hours then review with microbiology results Chronic Osteomyelitis
Piperacillin/tazobactam 4.5g 3 times a day IV Flucloxacillin 1g 4 times daily Tablet. Consider adding Rifampicin 300mg TDS for initial 2 weeks of 6 week course.

MRSA suspected/confirmed: Linezolid 600mg 2 times a day IV or tablet plus Piperacillin/Tazobactam 4.5g 3 times daily IV. Penicillin allergy:Tigecycline 100mg stat IV then 50mg bd IV. MRSA suspected/confirmed: Linezolid 600mg 2 times daily IV/or Tablet plus Piperacillin/Tazobactam 4.5g 3 times daily IV for 48 hours then review. Penicillin Allergy:Clindamycin 600mg 4 times a day tablet.

data.text: All doses are based on normal renal function. Use the renal dose calculator (http://pharm/asg/renaldoses.aspx) to adjust dosing in renal impairment.
Duration of Therapy
10.3.1 The duration of antibiotics for chronic osteomyelitis will depend on clinical response, but should not be less than 4 weeks (ideally at least 6 weeks),and may require months of therapy.
Early Podiatrist/foot health review is essential;
Consider vascular review if evidence of limb Ischaemia;
Consider orthopaedic referral if evidence of mid or rear foot bone involvement.

10.3.2 Most diabetic foot infections require some surgical intervention ranging from minor sharp debridement carried out in the community by podiatrists to major resection and amputation carried out in the acute sector. Wounds must also be properly dressed and pressure offloaded. They should be followed up regularly. An ischaemic foot may require re-vascularisation.
Recommendations with Osteomyelitis Care
Keep antibiotic prescribing to the essential minimum;
Prescribe an antibiotic only where there is likely to be a clear clinical benefit and for as short a time as possible;
Refer to and comply with MEHT policy on infection prevention to minimise the risk of a health care acquired infection.
Datix/ Breach Reporting
All untoward events involving patient safety are reported to the risk management department by way of Datix Web. This should be completed by the staff member(s) involved.
The findings from investigations relating to incidents involving the care of diabetes foot-care problems will be discussed at the monthly department meeting of the diabetes hospital team.
Audit
Compliance with this policy will be audited by the members of the diabetes

footcare team at least once every three years. They will present their fundings at an audit meeting with the medical department,. Any issues will be escalated to Clinical Directors and Divisional Managers for action.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Communication and Implementation
Approved guidelines are sent via email to all members of the diabetes footcare staff.
After approval, a copy of the guideline is published on the MEHT intranet and website and any staff teaching required will be undertaken.
